resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The hart is shown resting on a badge of rosemary, known to have been a personal badge of Anne of Bohemia. Appropriately, it has also been associated with memory, most famously by Shakespeare's Ophelia ("there's rosemary, that's for remembrance"). The green pigment has darkened with time, as on the recto.
resource.chars: The hart is shown resting on a badge of rosemary, known to have been a personal badge of Anne of Bohemia. Appropriately, it has also been associated with memory, most famously by Shakespeare's Ophelia ("there's rosemary, that's for remembrance"). The green pigment has darkened with time, as on the recto.

<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M107.96364,541.53455h224.06909v0h224.06909v220.87636v220.87636h-224.06909h-224.06909v-220.87636z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"annotation":null,"nonHoverStrokeColor":["Color",0,0.74902,1],"editable":true,"deleteIcon":null,"rotationIcon":null,"group":null}" id="rectangle_455cb3df-4d5a-4724-af97-7e2d78b731ce" fill-opacity="0.00001" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="3" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The realistic white hart on the verso of the Diptych is a masterpiece of medieval English animal painting. It was probably based on a real-life model; Richard is known to have been given a white stag in 1393. Leucism in deer (and other animals) is a recessive gene that is rare but not unheard of, and is distinct from albinism in that it isn't a total lack of pigmentation. Presumably the model for the painting was a leucistic deer. The antlers and crown were probably meant to be distinguished by gold stippling but it was never completed.
resource.chars: The realistic white hart on the verso of the Diptych is a masterpiece of medieval English animal painting. It was probably based on a real-life model; Richard is known to have been given a white stag in 1393. Leucism in deer (and other animals) is a recessive gene that is rare but not unheard of, and is distinct from albinism in that it isn't a total lack of pigmentation. Presumably the model for the painting was a leucistic deer. The antlers and crown were probably meant to be distinguished by gold stippling but it was never completed.
